captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

The RS200 was designed
to be nothing other
than a rally car.

It didn't have to look like
a Sierra or an Escort or

something that had to be
sold in the showrooms.

Much like the Lancia Stratos and
the 037, it was designed
to win rallies.

It was a prototype in the
correct sense of the word.

But of course, through those
homologation rules, Ford had
to build 200 of them.

So they had to be road cars
as well, leading to those
extraordinary street versions.
This is one of them.
And I'm going to drive it.
I've always wanted to do this.
[REVVING ENGINE]
What a rattle box.

I think we're gonna
have some fun.
Good God.

So, Stig Blomqvist, Kalle
Grundel, the people that kept

me awake at night when I
was a kiddie watching
rallying on BBC Two.
Finally get to try and be you.
Look at this driving position.
Look at this cabin.
Tiny.
See if we can not stall it.
Oh, that's hilarious.

I can't actually see
too much out of it.

Oh, it's just a collection
of really nasty noises.
But you know what?

Nasty noises in the context of
a Group B car, good noises.

The RS200 was designed
to be functional.

It had short overhangs and
enough intakes to ingest
massive amounts of air.

About the easiest car to stall
I've ever driven, though.
I've got a handbrake.
Does the handbrake work?
Handbrake works.

So as I try and kangaroo through
southwest London's

suburbs, maybe time
to think about the
specification of this car.

The engine, and this is where
we're going to be a bit geeky,
is 1.8 liters.

As a child, I got this
all a bit about face.

I thought this had a Sierra
Cosworth engine.

Two-liter with that famous
Cosworth block that went on to

fire everything from Sierra
Cosworth, Sapphire Cosworth,
Escort Cosworth.

You know, the definitive
four-cylinder engine.
This is different.

This has got a BDT, for the
geeks out there, and it's

based on the famous BDA, which
was the engine made famous in
the Mark II Escort.

So it's immensely strong and
can produce enormous power.

As many of you will know, the
RS200 had a very short rally

life that we'll discuss
in a minute.

But it went on to do many other
things, including Pike's
Peak and RallyCross, mainly.

And the BDT apparently, legend
has it, can produce up to 800
horsepower.

But this one is a
stock road car.
It's owned by Ford in the UK.

It has about 250 horsepower,
maybe a little less, about 200

foot-pounds of torque, and it
weighs about 1,150 kilograms.

So it's not that heavy, but
it's no great fireball.

Top speed, they claimed a little
over 140 miles an hour,

but 0 to 60 in five seconds
because of the four-wheel
drive system.
The four-wheel drive system.

This is where the RS200
is fascinating.

So, much like the Stratos,
Ford decided it wanted a

mid-engine car with a short
wheelbase to be
able to change direction.

Rallying is, after all, about
direction changes in a car
that's agile, easily agitated.

So it went down a mid-engine
route.

But for weight distribution,
it put gearbox
ahead of the engine.

So underneath this
gear lever here,
there's a great big lump.
You'll see it in a second.
That is the gearbox.

The gearbox is there and
the engine's behind me.
It's an in-line four cylinder.

So what happens in the RS200
is that the power is taken

forwards to the gearbox
and then taken
back to the back axle.

Now how can I described
this to you.

It's like a Nissan GTR
going backwards.

So an RS200 going forwards is
almost identical in terms

layout as a GTR going
backwards.

It does mean there's quite a bit
of transmission noise and

clonk and rattle, all the
half-shafts and prop-shafts

trying to get power to somewhere
odd where it doesn't
want to go naturally.

It just makes it the most
fascinating bit of history.
I love it.
I absolutely love it.
And I wish videos did smells.

Because this just smells
of motor sport.

Smells of motor sport
goodness.

Today the RS200 strikes an
interesting shape on the road,
and here on its own.

It doesn't actually
look that old.

Partly because many modern
performance cars now have

gaping mesh-covered holes like
this 26-year-old car.

The machine itself
was assembled
at the Reliant factory.

Yes, the same people that
built the famous
three-wheeler.

And the finish was-- how
can I put this--
rough and ready.

But it was designed to rally,
not to win a panel gap
competition.

The interior on the 200 road
cars was a smash and grab raid

on the Ford of Europe's
parts bin.
But it kind of worked.

The rest was pure motor
sport fantasy.

Twin coilovers at each corner
and a vast, single-piece rear

clamshell that gave excellent
access to the engine bay.

The RS200 appears dumpy to
those who don't know, but

beautiful to those
of us do know.

It's a fascinating car to
drive now, the RS200.
Terrible at low speed.

But once you get it up on its
toes, the inherent rightness

of the size and weight
distribution shines through.

The four-wheel drive system
makes it want to understeer.

But trailing throttle into
a turn sorts that out.

Then full power brings
it straight again.

It feels like it could handle
750 horsepower, which is

exactly what it ended up doing
at Pike's Peak with Stig.

But the RS200's story is one
of pain and mistakes.

Its development was
painfully slow.

It didn't manage to compete in
a world championship event in

1985, debuting in '86, by which
time Peugeot's 205 and

Lancia's Delta S4
were unbeatable.
And then came Portugal.
[INAUDIBLE]

scenes as spectators lined the
roadside and attempted to

touch 500-horsepower cars as
they drifted past them.

It was only ever going
to end one way.

And tragically for Ford, it was
Joaquim Santos involved in

an accident that would kill
three spectators.
Group B was done for.

This is the great fascination
of the RS200.
It was late arriving.

It only ever scored a third
place on Rally Sweden in '86.

And it was actually a little too
heavy to compete with the
French and Italian teams.

But to many people, me included,
it still kind of

defines Group B, a form of motor
sport that captured the

imagination so profoundly that
companies like Ford felt

compelled to drop millions
developing a car that didn't

even offer tangible marketing
crossover into
a production car.

As a competition machine, and as
a sales tool, the RS200 was
sadly a failure.

A magnificent failure that we
should all be thankful for.

The same could we said of this
lump of green loveliness.

The Audi Sport Quattro was
Germany's answer to the

Lancia, the Peugeot,
and the Ford.

Audi's position within rallying
couldn't have been
more different to Ford's.

The Quattro had profoundly
changed the sport
in the early '80s.

But the company had lost the
initiative and needed a car to

compete with the
new prototypes.

But Audi's approach to rallying
was more pragmatic.

It was building a brand on the
back of four-wheel drive and

the inherent safety it provided
in road cars.

And it insisted that its rally
car at least resemble the
stuff it sold in showrooms.

It needed a more powerful, agile
machine, so it chopped

320 millimeters from the
wheelbase of the standard

Quattro, added wider wings,
and took a 2.1-liter,

five-cylinder motor out
to 306 horsepower.

Like the RS200, Audi had to
build 200 road version to
comply with the regulations.

But this was a fully trimmed
road car with all the luxuries

you'd expect from something that
was twice as expensive as
a regular Quattro.

The problem was, the Sport
Quattro was now so nose-heavy,

it understeered like
a 911 on 2CV tires.

This is one of the 200 Sport
Quattros built for the road.

In fact, there might have
been a few less.

There's a bit of conjecture
out there.

But I don't want to
get involved in
that particular argument.
It feels incredibly special.

To a rally obsessive like me,
this is a very special moment.

I've never sat in one of these,
let alone driven one.

Immobilizer, a good '90s-style
immobilizer.
Key in there, no throttle.
Rumbles a bit.

What's it like to drive
a Sport Quattro?

First of all, it feels very
contemporary Audi to me, and
that's in a good way.

I love the typefaces
on the dials.
It feels tiny in here as well.

For the first and perhaps last
time, the seat, for me-- a
massive 5' 7" of me--

is almost at the back of its
reach in terms of leg length.
Gearbox throw is quite long.
Engine is lovely.
It's laggy.

But it's torque-y
and, oh, wow.

So the gearbox, the throw is
quite long on the lever.

And it's got turbo lag, 3,000
RPM it just starts to build,
boost gauge flickers.

It's quick, you know,
properly quick.
I like it.
I really like it.

Odd sensation in through this
quicker stuff, it's actually
quite nice and stable.

As it naturally wants to
understeer because of all that

immense weight out front,
ahead of the front axle.
I love it.

What did it feel
like in period?

306 horsepower, 260 foot-pounds
of torque, a

little over 1,250 kilograms
in weight.

It must have felt
like a lunatic.

I think we tried to work out
how many cars have gone

sub-five seconds to 62 miles an
hour from a standstill on

piston heads, and it
was about five.

This was one of the
world's fastest
cars when it was launched.
Still feels quick now.

It's actually quite hard trying
to think about how to

describe the differences
between the two cars.

And even to flip on its head,
I'm trying to find the
similarities.

The RS200 was just
a prototype.

It is just a little body shell
with amazing suspension and

components designed to go fast
that happens to have a couple
of seat in it.
This is a proper road car.
It's beautifully trimmed.
The seats are comfortable.

It's got heated seats,
electric windows.
It's lovely.

I could imagine getting in this
car, driving it to Geneva
for the weekend.
I really can.

I'm surprised at how
usable it is.

I read that it was a bit of sort
of turbo lag nightmare.
Yeah, it's got some lag.

But that just adds to
the experience.

If you're gonna get in the sport
quattro, I want lag.

I don't want some
super-responsive, normally
aspirated engine.

I can get that in
a modern car.
This is different.

And then there's the
[INAUDIBLE] noise.
I love it.
I love it.
I want it.
I want it.
But it's 149,000 pounds.

It's impossible to compare these
two as road cars today.

One is a competition car with
license plates, the other, a

staggeringly fast street car
contorted to go rallying.

As competition cars, neither of
these machines quite lived

up to the investment and
care lavished on them.
But that doesn't matter now.

Because they remind us of
when rallying was great.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Group B Worship: Ford RS200 and Audi Sport Quattro - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: Nigel D

comments.text:
'... of when rallying was GREAT.'

Yes, exactly. It was. What it has gone on to become isn't too bad either, 
but the end of the group B days were a very sad slide back into mediocrity. 
We'd gone from 30 or 40 years of having somewhat tuned up road cars, ending 
with rather wonderful little rear drivers like the Escort and the Datto 
1600, to ...sudden overnight balls out insanity. It suddenly went from 40 
years of gradually improving water pistols, to real 9mm race specials, 
Lazar sights and all. Forget paint guns, this was AK-47s at arms length. 
You just stood, awestruck, like all those dopey fans on stage, who really 
didn't seem to care if they got killed, as long as you could see Rohl or 
Vatenin or somebody go past like an F1 car. And they sounded as wicked as 
they were, perhaps none more than the 5 cyl Audi Quatros, which sounded 
nothing in the world like a roadgoing Audi, they sounded like the 4 
horsemen of the Apocalypse, set to Wagner, played at 11/10 over the full 
Led Zeppelin PA system. If that noise didn't get your blood to zing, then 
petrol flowed in some funny places, but not through your veins, you poor 
sad little child... The hippies drool on about the summer of love, and 
flower power. Petrol heads drool on about group B. We have a reason. There 
was never anything like it before, and there never will be again. It was 
everything you've ever heard about '80s excess and cocaine high, all in one 
crazy season. All the Spandex and speed, all the un-complicated sex and 
very complicated drivelines, all concentrated like one BIG line on a 
mirror. It was amazing, and it will never be like that again. ... then, we 
went back to water pistols...﻿

If you want a low mileage 13k to be exact, Quattro Sport, there is a one 
owner car for sale in this months Classic & Sports Car.
Your's for £495,995, now that's what i call a solid investment.
Several years ago they were changing hands for around £80k if you could 
find one that is.
This car has 13,000 genuine miles on the clock and every service receipt 
and bill since new.
It's had a full professional detailing overhaul, and is better than factory 
fresh, the photographs are stunning.
Half a million seems a lot of money, but i's a terribly rare care and very 
desirable. ﻿

comments.author: King Geedorah

comments.text:
+Nagy Szilard Yeah, look, what goes around comes around. Right now the 
'international governing body' in charge of motorcycle roadracing, 
superbikes and MotoGP, is figuring out how to give the European factories 
an edge over the Japanese, who have shitloads more money and these days, 
better engineering. The steps taken are numerous, but the intention is 
clear. The europeans will find ways to beat the Japanese, no matter what it 
takes. And they will try to do this with the pretence, the appearance, that 
these are open and fair rules for all. Trouble is they have conflicting 
desires. They want to have Yamaha and Honda, they're getting Suzuki back, 
and they want Kawasaki as well, but they want to gift the thing to Aprilia 
and Ducati. That calls for some fancy footwork, which is going on as I 
type...
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:

rally. Everything since has been a sad joke.

Quattro would look so much better with shorter overhangs. Those overhangs

But looks aren't important for Group B. Wish I could go back to 80's, man 
it was such a cool time to live and be part of motorsport. But we won't 
ever get back to that  considering how everything is "evolving".﻿
comments.author: Atrax1207

comments.text: Ford is a bucket ﻿

Iv driven 3 different rs200's . Its a rally car, drive it like it and its 
great! Try to plod away from stop at 2000 rpm, erm no!﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:
even thought it's for the good, I think that the audi sport quattro's 
change in wheelbase compared to the normal quattro looks like crap. it 
looks like one of the "people" from cars while they are jumping or talking.﻿
comments.author: Campbell Gildersleeve

comments.text:
I love these group B monster rally cars, but who wouldn't. But there is 
something, that I don't quite like about them, it was almost an era in the 
WRC where, the manufactures didn't care. It was more about squeezing 50 
more bhp out of that 2 litre engine, rather than making the technical rally 
cars that are the modern WRC. However it was an epic time in motorsport.
RIP - Joaquim Santos﻿
comments.author: Shane Howell

comments.text:
I now want to drive a Sport Quattro so badly :) Even if it's not comparable 
with my Evo in ways of modernization and technology, I just want to feel 
how the first AWD felt like driving around the corners. Without 
electronics, just pure mechanics.﻿
comments.author: Chris M

comments.text:
+Qnickel27 Yea, not the First 4 or A Wheel drive, but it was the first with 
Differential. Before Audi 4 or all Wheel drive were slow going terrain 
vehicles, often military. and with slow i mean 30 Km/h.

And if that's not enough the Evolving Left foor breaking to lauch them out 
of the courners which Audi drivers perfected. The drivers of the Ur and 
Sport Quattro deserve as much props as audi.

not the first awd system, but ur right an early eaxmple that was mainly

Lancia Delta s4 And audi Sport Quattro is imo the .... I have no Words for

comments.text: 149 000 pounds.... Thats a new supercar.﻿
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha there are a lot of cars that don't lose money. you just need to 
know the market and find the right car
comments.author: Pedro Macário

comments.text:
+Pedro Macário
You almost cant worry about such things when youre talking about cars. 
Modern or classic. Unless its an old racing Ferrari. Then youre making 
money instead of losing.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text: +Janusha and depreciation...
comments.author: Pedro Macário

comments.text:
+clougher293
Well I used to drive a Lotus Elise when I lived and worked in the UK but I 
didnt know much about cars back then. At the company where I worked, people 
had 2 Lambos, some Ferraris, a bunch of Jap racers such as NSX, EVO and 
Imprezza. I would have loved to still have that Lotus today when I could 
appreciate it more. Not quite a "classic" but will probably be considered 
classic one day.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha Similar story with my father; in 1993 he bought an Autocar 
magazine with an Aston Martin DB7 on the front, and swore to himself he'd 
own one. 10 years ago he managed to purchase one, in the exact same colour 
and spec as the Autocar cover car - still have it and have put over 70k 
miles on it :)
I see what you're saying, and to some extent I agree - but I am 19, have 
very limited mechanical knowledge and my only car is a 1961 Triumph Herald 
S! It can be a headache owning such a car at times, but in all fairness 
it's been quite reliable (due to the simplicity of these classics, less on 
them obviously means less to go wrong!) and any broken/worn parts have been 
easy to source.
It's all subjective of course, and funny to see alternate views; Audi Sport 
Quattro for £149k - solid, future investment or overpriced, out dated 
technology? New Ferrari for £149k - latest and greatest tech all crammed 
into a very impressive performance car, or merely another flash modern 
motor that will lose tens of thousands in depreciation?
It's great that people have such varying opinions, I'd hate to see all the 
roads filled with the same stuff!
comments.author: clougher293

comments.text:
+clougher293 Yes yes youre right ofcourse. When my father grew up, he 
bought a Cadillac Eldorado Seville from 1957. Because back when he was a 
kid, that would be like owning a big Lamborghini to a kid today.

Anyway. Given an unlimited budget, I still would feel the responsibility of 
owning an old classic like that, daunting. Id much rather go with new stuff 
that, if I break it, can be easily replaced.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha In my opinion, the value of these cars is based on nostalgia and 
simple supply and demand. People grew up watching these beasts dominate the 
rallying world, if they come into money in later life, they're more likely 
to be drawn to a dream car of when they were young than a modern supercar, 
that'll simply be out-dated old tech in a few years.
Also, it's easy to walk into a dealership and order a brand new Ferrari or 
Lambo, but if it's a one of 200 homologation special from 30 years ago that 
you're after, you have to wait, search and seek out one, and even then it 
may be the wrong colour, spec etc.. that you're after.
Value for money? Not at all, but cars like these tug on heart strings like 
no modern supercar can.
comments.author: clougher293

comments.text:
+leo lion
You see these hundreds of videos. People running after supercars in London. 
Bugattis and all kinds of hyper-stuff all the time. But Ive never actually 
seen that when Ive been to London myself. 

And yeah. I would love my old Lotus back.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
Yeah in the UK you do see some nice cars but they are so random. Couple 
GTR's around the area I  live (25 miles north of London) seen Lambos and 
Ferraris (funny I usually see women driving them) but I have to say someone 
had a Lancia Delta int' and it was the best thing Ive ever seen! (Other 
then one time I was in London town and actually saw someone driving a 
Mclaren F1) I think Lotus now are a car for the driving enthusiast rather 
then the 'look at me in my car' type person. They are super agile like a 
fighter jet and that cant be a bad thing - It all depends on the type of 
statement the individual is trying to make.
comments.author: leo lion

comments.text:
+leo lion
Well..... There was a time when I worked in England when we were driving 
around in Lamborghinis, Ferraris Lotuses and some NSX and Subaru Imprezza 
stuff... Ironically I wasnt very into sportscars at the time. I drove a 
Lotus Elise and thought it was an embarrassing plastic bucket next to all 
those other things at the company... But fuck me sideways. I would have 
murdered for that Lotus today.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
Well I guess thats something Im never going to have to worry about haha. Im 
the leader of the never have much money and if I did I wouldn't spend it on 
classic cars club ;)

comments.text:

Thats for people like Jay Leno who is president of the 
more-money-than-sense club. If I owned supercars, it would be new stuff. I 
would be FAR too worried about breaking old classics.

comments.text:

anyway.

comments.text:

No a classic painting does not age like a classic car. Its very extremely 
rarely a good investment.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:

you have true Audi Quattros. Its a bit like saying why buy an old picture 
from Van Gogh when you can buy crayons and draw one yourself. History is 
worth a lot more then modern tech.
comments.author: leo lion

comments.text:

But for that price... You can get a 2005 Lamborghini and a great new

comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:

italians would break much sooner.

The notion of supercars breaking down is from the early 90s... Today, you

And the repair cost and difficulty of finding parts would probably be

comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:

For 149 000 pounds, you get a second hand Ferrari 430 Scuderia AND a second

comments.text:
Video's like this make me hate these new wiz-bang-gadget cars even 
more...with all the so called progress in technology and safety, the 
emotions of driving are forever lost. Group A and B cars were astonishing 
and had all the tech you really ever need...real cars for real pilots. ﻿
comments.author: 647killa

comments.text:
+Janusha 6m 11s line to line, not gate to gantry: Porsche 956 1984. Right, 
everyone - try and beat it lol!
comments.author: marsvltor2

comments.text:
+Janusha I really did enjoy reading the comments you posted here. Just 
wanted to tell you that it was a good read. I mean I both learned something 
about the american car industry and what happened economically in the west 
these past years. Gotta' ask you though. Didn't the americans have a market 
in europe through SAAB? I know it's a swedish production, but wasn't GM the 
people behind the engines? At least until they dropped it I mean.
comments.author: Kristian Søndergaard

comments.text:
+Janusha Yes but I've seen people flying confederate flags, and when a 
civic has a larger spoiler than most supercars it makes me want to cry
comments.author: Sean Taylor

comments.text:
+Sean Taylor
Yes well... This day last year I drove from Vancouver down to USA in a 
yellow Audi TT on summer tyres. Canada is a wonderful country in many ways. 
And people can have whatever favourites they like ofcourse. Im just trying 
to say it as it is.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha I know there are more than Enough Canadian redneck dumbasses, I'm 
surrounded by and related to them. One of my mom's cousins who is in his 
mid - late thirties admitted to being "very short bus" in public. I never 
said the politics behind the cars was anything but complete bullshit, thats 
why I stay away from it, and most of my favorite cars are '90s era japanese 
sports cars, not american cars. Also before anyone says anything, I said 
'90s era japanese SPORTS cars so civics/integras/preludes do not fit the 
description
comments.author: Sean Taylor

comments.text:
+Sean Taylor
Yeah well... I spent 3 months visiting long lost family in Canada this time 
last year and drove around Calgary, Vancouver and down to the northern bit 
of the US and there are PLENTY of Canadians who buy into all that american 
flag-swinging lunacy and their wild myths and tall tales.

Im just tired of hearing it in every car-related discussion how them 
murcans arrived at the Nurburgring and ALL claimed woooorld records on 
their first god damn weekend.

American cars, like any american product, is about cheap plastic for the 
flagwaving masses. This has always been their goal. Its not like they TRIED 
to make quality and failed to do so. Quality and tech costs money. Money 
that they previously werent willing to spend and money that they currently 
dont have.

American car industry was always about the patriotism and the hype. The 
COMPLETE lack of independant US car magazines and the fact that they are 
the only country in the world without critical, factual car shows on TV, 
means they mistake any corporate hype, any media stunt performed by the 
big-3 gets accepted as truth.

Im SO tired of having flags waved in my face in every vaguelly MURCA 
related topic. And when I was in Canada last year, Canadians were all very 
aware of what I mean by that.

Which is why I ask such questions. Instead of saying the US car industry 
failed. Im saying... Can you name ONE SINGLE internationally competitive US 
car from this decade or the last?

The answer is no... Hell no.. And if the answer is no, then what... FAILING 
to sell cars to the 500 million people of Europe, is just that. A failure. 
Not some business decision. When they FAIL to survive in a market that 
sells 12 million cars a year domestically... How is this not a monumental 
failure of epic proportions.

When they accept MORE bailouts than the entire country of Greece has got 
from the European Union and STILL Chrysler was given away to Fiat for free, 
Ford turned to Ford of Europe for help and GM... GM abandoned 89 major 
plants all across the US, cashed in their bailout billions and 
singlehandedly bankrupted an entire state when they essentially fled the 
country, moding the backbone of US manufacturing to China and Korea. Today 
70% of GM is asian.

No... Not American cars built in Asia... Gm today makes most their money 
selling rebadged Korean Daewoo to China. Bought and paid for by bailout 
billions that were set aside to secure the future for US / Canadian car 
industry. So how the HELL is this not a complete and utter failure.

How could they POSSIBLY have run themselves further into the ground. But 
americans still wave that big foam nr1 finger for US superiority because 
they run a faith and belief based system and dont really ever look shit up. 

Nuff siad.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha I do remember saying I DIDN'T like the viper, and I never said 
american cars beat every supercar on the planet, I named one. For the 
patriotism bullshit, I'm Canadian and proudly so. I don't need perfect, 
leather wrapped interiors for a car to be good, if I could have any ferrari 
I would have an F40. I'm not saying new tech is the devil but I happen to 
really enjoy driving standard and most manufacturers except a few smaller 
British companies and the 'muricans don't even give you the option to 
choose. I will admit, however that I didn't look too deeply into the lap 
times, but I don't think it is that far of a stretch that the zr1 could 
post a good time. I'm not saying American cars are the best cars in the 
world because, clearly, they're not but I do not agree with this single 
minded "All American cars are complete rubbish" bullshit. They are not all 
as bad as a base model '94 saturn with 492,000 kms on it
comments.author: Sean Taylor

comments.text:
+Sean Taylor
Oh christ.. Not again with the god damn Nurburgring... These ridiculously 
misleading lap times were originally set by GM and Chrysler in 2008 smack 
in the middle of their own bankruptcy. When Obama pulled the big3 infront 
of congress and asked them how they were able to go so incredibly bankrupt 
in a market that sells 11-12 million cars a year,

They were told to prove themselves "internationally competitive" to deserve 
Obamas hundreds of billions in bailouts... 

So off they went... To the Nurburgring to set spectacularly misleading lap 
times with full factory race crews and cars as "stock" as Lance Armstrong 
at Tour`d France.

Coming home emptyhanded... With hundreds of billions of dollars at stake, 
just wasnt an option.

So... These are MEDIA STUNTS. Performed with modded cars with rollcages, 
stripped out interiors on LeMans racing tyres with full factory backed race 
crews.

Then they return to the all-too-willing GM sponsored american motoring 
press with stories of how they went to the Nurburgring, Europes own 
benchmark, and killed, raped, smoked, owned, destroyed, every supercar on 
the planet...

Well... Who else DOES this? Except Nissan and now the americans? So who are 
they claiming to "beat" ? This idea of the Ring as some kind of 
international benchmark where we all go to see whats "best" is an all 
american myth created to give these misleading american runs some 
credibility. And now many others have jumped on the trend. Especially those 
who target the US market where people have such faith in this.

So now... In ANY car related topic, we have to hear how cheaply built 
american steel and plastic "beats" every supercar on the planet. I 
wonder... How likely is this really. And where is the evidence. But 
americans dont need no evidence. They never question any claim aslong as it 
supports an entirely one-sided american superiority.

Both Corvette and Viper claiming fastest production cars when none of them 
ever were... For the Cadillac, they simply INVENTED a 4 door salooncar 
record and claimed it on the spot. At what time does it ever get 
embarrassing? This may go down well in the US where nobody ever looks stuff 
up but please... Dont push these stunts on me.

And... To say you would prefer a z28 over a Ferrari 458 is to say you 
really prefer a lump of coal to a diamond. Nobody would ever say that 
unless you were spoonfed patriotism from childhood. American musclecars 
dont offer modern tech because they cant afford it... Not because old and 
cheap is better than new and expensive.

And finally... The Viper... Is possibly the worst sportscar to ever roll 
out of a proper factory. Its the single most crashed sportscar in history. 
Go to Wreckedexotics. com and look up Vipers. There are 23 pages with over 
700 pictures. Thats like 1 in 30 Vipers ever built, crashed on ONE webpage.

So forgive me but.... How the hell is this "internationally competitive"
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha I didn't want to mention the viper because I don't like it, but I 
was sure I'd be flamed by someone if I didn't. The C6 zr1 and z06 posted 
7m19s and 7m22s lap times and when they did the fastest lap posted by the 
Nissan gtr was a 7m24s time. The biggest edge American car companies have 
even over japanese manufacturers is, in my opinion, that they still offer 
the option of a manual transmission, I would prefer the new z28 over a 458 
for that very reason
comments.author: Sean Taylor

comments.text:
+Sean Taylor
Oh... These are examples of internationally competitive american cars ??

Well... Saleen S7 wasnt even a crashtested and government approved 
production car. It was sold as a ready-built american kit-car. The Ford GT 
was never american even tho it was assembled there. 

Corvette C6, Camaro and tuneshopped Mustangs were never even sold outside 
america... It remains to be seen if GM will launch the Corvette C7 in 
Europe. But now that they made the decision to pull Chevrolet / GM out of 
Europe, they MIGHT try to relaunch Cadillac and Corvette as seperate brands 
but youknow... I doubt it.

If THIS is what you mean by "internationally competitive" then its worse 
than I thought.

The Viper.... Was never sold outside the US and havent seen a year of 
profit from its unveiling in 1989 til its bankruptcy in 2009. Thats 20 
straight years of loss. The new one is a whole new beast under Fiat 
leadership. But even that one will never be sold in Europe. You simply 
cannot get away with a 8 and a half liter 10 mpg musclecar here.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha  C6 corvette, C7 corvette, the new camaro z28, ford gt, I guess I 
should mention the viper, mustang boss 302, saleen s7
comments.author: Sean Taylor

comments.text:
+Bensaves
Wouldnt pass modern safety regulations, wouldnt pass modern emissions. 
Which is why many companies put modern suspension, wheels and engines into 
old chassis to kind of try and get that old-car magic with new, reliable 
tech. The americans especially seem to have a fondness for kit-cars and 
tuneshop jobs. There is a hell of alot of junk but Singer Porsches seem 
good.

But yeah... They should allow more exciting cars. Id love to see forexample 
Ferrari and Jaguar making the same old stuff as they did in the 60s but 
with todays knowledge of downforce and handling. No electronics, just a 
beautiful little engine in a tiny car.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
Couldn't agree more. It always saddens me a bit when I realise that ABS is 
mandated by law in my country and cars are shouted down from the rooftops 
if they don't offer Traction, stability and fun control, or don't offer 
bluetooth. I would love someone to make a performance car with a well 
sorted chassis powered by an old school power plant. Just an honest 
performance car not muddied by all the bullshit that the car industry 
demands now
comments.author: Bensaves

comments.text:
+Janusha Nostalgia is just a by product of cars that were built without 
being governed by economics, politics and regulations.
You should keep in mind that car makers were going to make engines more 
efficient anyway. 
I wish auto makers would certain build performance cars without all these 
gimmicks. This would make a cheaper car, but in the end, it would be more 
of a purist's car.
I want something with AWD torque vectoring and a nice engine with forced 
induction, but using a manual gearbox. That's it.
The GT86 is close, but all I'd to it, is remove the stereo and speakers.
comments.author: slip88

comments.text:
+PSRBF6
Look at the american car industry. They denied progress and kept making 
their old stuff for decades past its sell-by-date while the rest of the 
world moved on.... Look how well it worked for them.

See if you can name ONE internationally competitive american built car from 
this decade or the last.

It all went bankrupt for them. While we like all that nostalgia and 
stuff... We simply wouldnt buy it.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
I salute your educated reply sir !! Glad to see a few enthusiasts still 
exist in this cold world.
comments.author: 647killa

comments.text:
That's pretty much how I'd put it.
You don't need a fancy Bluetooth connected touch screen display, or heated 
electric seats, or an automatic gearbox, or extra carpet for sound 
deadening, and driving aids.
Economics and politics ruined car culture.
People just don't understand why car enthusiasts love older cars.
